Situation A. Folding Paper to Make Cylinders

Teri and Wyn each use an 8 x 11 sheet of paper to make a cylinder.

Teri’s Cylinder

h = 8

Teri tapes the shorter ends of the sheet of paper together to form her cylinder.

Wyn’s Cylinder

h =11

Wyn tapes the longer ends of the sheet of paper together to form her cylinder.

No, the volumes of two cylinders are different. Some students might want to compare volumes of two cylinders by filling them with sand, rice, grain, etc. After filling Teri’s cylinder with sand, they can pour it into Wyn’s cylinder. Then they will see that they have leftovers in Teri’s cylinder while Wyn’s is full. Or, if they fill Wyn’s first and pour it into Teri’s, they will see that they cannot fill up Teri’s with Wyn’s. It means that Teri’s cylinder has greater volume than Wyn’s.

Other students may calculate the volumes of cylinders. They can see that the volume of Teri’s cylinder is greater than that of Wyn’s.

  • Teri’s cylinder

The height = 8

The circumference of base circle = 11; the diameter of base circle = 11÷π 3.5; the radius of base circle ≈3.5 ÷2=1.75

So, the volume of Teri’s cylinder = π × 1.75 × 1.75 × 8 ≈76.93

  • Wyn’s cylinder

The height = 11

The circumference of base circle = 8; the diameter of base circle = 8÷π 2.5; the radius of base circle ≈2.5 ÷2=1.25

So, the volume of Teri’s cylinder = π × 1.25 × 1.25 × 11 ≈53.97

Situation B. Designing a New Smoothie Bar

The Nutritious Juice Company also sells rectangular shaped nutrition bars made from the same ingredients as their smoothies. They are called Smoothie Bars. They want a new design for their Smoothie Bar.

The manager suggested the following design:
1. To find the amount of packaging, they need the surface area. Describe a strategy to find the surface area. What is the surface area?

The surface area of a package is the area of package when you flat the package on a plane. You can cut the paper package of Smoothie Bar and lay down on the grid to measure lengths or count unit squares.
2. What is the volume of the bar? Explain your strategy.

To find the volume of cylinder, you need to know the area of base and the height of the cylinder. From the net, you can see the height is 4 cm. For the area of base, you can see that the radius of the circle is 3 cm; the area of base is π×3×3=28.26 cm2. So, the volume of cylinder is 28.26×4=113.04 cm3.

Situation C. Zeke asks, What’s New with Volume?

After experimenting with cylinders, Zeke claimed that there was nothing new about volume. Examine his reasoning. Does this make sense? Explain why.

Zeke’s Reasoning

The volume V of a cylinder is the area of its base times its height h. V = area of base x h. This is the same equation for volume of right prisms.
Yes. The volume of every right prism can be found by finding the area of the base, which is one layer, and then multiplying this by the height, which is the number of layers.
